body_html:
@wt-huang Anyway, maybe you should have suggested a more mnemonic command instead of

python tf_upgrade.py --infile renames_v2.py --outfile foo-upgraded.py

You could have suggested, e.g.

python tf_upgrade.py --infile path_to_your_file.py --outfile path_to_upgraded_file.py

Also, I haven't tried yet your suggestion, but why would we need to change any import? Is this script supposed to be used in any other way than from the command line? If yes, then maybe two scripts could have been created to solve this problem of needing to change imports.

python tf_upgrade.py --infile renames_v2.py --outfile foo-upgraded.py
You could have suggested, e.g.
python tf_upgrade.py --infile path_to_your_file.py --outfile path_to_upgraded_file.py
Also, I haven't tried yet your suggestion, but why would we need to change any import? Is this script supposed to be used in any other way than from the command line? If yes, then maybe two scripts could have been created to solve this problem of needing to change imports.
body:
@wt-huang Anyway, maybe you should have suggested a more mnemonic command instead of 

```python tf_upgrade.py --infile renames_v2.py --outfile foo-upgraded.py```

You could have suggested, e.g.

```python tf_upgrade.py --infile path_to_your_file.py --outfile path_to_upgraded_file.py```

Also, I haven't tried yet your suggestion, but why would we need to change any import? Is this script supposed to be used in any other way than from the command line? If yes, then maybe two scripts could have been created to solve this problem of needing to change imports.
